field_edited_text.value:
Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route

ooy yygdL





dential buildings on the north of Lancaster Street for a block and
a half west of Broadway will be about 75 feet from the express-
way which at this point is a single deck elevated structure. About
20 houses are involved. A few houses at two or three other points
in this general area would be about the same distance away.

Along the Northern Route the expressway is elevated for approxi-
mately a mile through a predominantly residential area running
from Bond Street to Kenwood Avenue. The distance between
the structure and nearby houses varies somewhat but would
seldom be over 60 feet and would be less in some places. No
count has been made of the number of adjacent houses, but it
would appear to be several hundred. In addition, there would be
some 20 to 30 houses in Armistead Gardens which might be un-
comfortably close to the expressway which again is elevated at
this point.

It is evident that proximity of elevated structures to residences
occurs to a much lesser extent along the Harbor Route than along
the Northern Route.

5. Close Proximity of Elevated Structures to Retail or Office Areas:
This situation does not exist on either route. While it might be
thought to occur on the Harbor Route where it runs between
Pratt and Camden Streets the clearance of all buildings between
these two streets will leave ample room for the elevated structure.
There will be approximately 150 feet between the buildings left
standing facing Pratt and Camden Streets and the main structure
of the expressway. The effect will be to open up the area and
the construction of the expressway should be an asset rather than
a liability to adjacent properties.





Number and Quality of Dwellings to be Demeolished

Total properties which would have to be acquired for the Northern
Route, the Harbor Route, and the sections in common are shown on
Table 2, divided between residential properties and commercial and in-
dustrial properties. Also shown are properties which would have to be
taken for the alternative methods of completing the inner ring. (Resi-
dential properties are defined as those wholly devoted to residential
purposes. A building with commercial use on the first floor and apart-
ments above would be classified as a commercial property.)

Omitting the sections in common, it will be seen that the Harbor
Route would require the acquisition of only 1,293 properties as against
2,729 for the Northern Route. Completing the inner ring with the
Harbor Route plan would also take fewer properties than completing
the inner ring using the Northern Route—510 properties against 1,089
properties.

TABLE 2
NUMBER OF PROPERTIES TO BE ACQUIRED BY TYPE

Route Properties Properties Properties

Norkhern Rowbe . . ovisysa sl 2,323 406 2,729

with Northern Route........... 838 251 1,089
